Award.AwardTitle: Spatial and Temporal Patterns of Upper Ocean Variability from the Drake Passage High-Resolution XBT/XCTD Observations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Using the frequent crossings of the Drake Passage by the RV/AS Gould as USAP supply ship to Palmer Station, UCSD researchers will continue the collection of upper ocean XBTs (expendable Bathythermograph for depth, temperature) and XTCD (expendable temperature, conductivity and depth profiler) salinity data in this natural chokepoint for the Antarctic Circumpolar Current (ACC). This will continue to yield hydrographic observations on seasonal to interannual timescales, and on spatial scales ranging from the current core to mesoscale eddies. These high-resolution, multi-repeat transects and depth profiles (up to 12-16 crossings per year) are quality controlled, archived and made available to the broader community in order to facilitate study of the modes of variability of the ACC, the dominant surface ocean current on the planet.

The Drake Passage XBT/XCTD transect time series now extends back to 1996, and continues to add to a number of key quantitative estimates of the long term trends in Southern Ocean fronts, surface water mass properties, their response to atmospheric forcing on climate relevant time scales, and their roles in driving the meridional overturning circulation of the Southern Ocean.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Southern Ocean is particularly sensitive to climate change, responding to winds that have increased and shifted over the past several decades and warming of more than one degree Celsius per century in the core of the Antarctic Circumpolar Current (ACC). Predicting the response of the Southern Ocean circulation to climate change requires a better understanding of changes in the ACC fronts and water masses and in the mesoscale eddy field that plays a critical role in exchanging momentum and heat across the ACC. The Southern Ocean is also a region of critical importance for the global carbon cycle. The future trajectory of carbon exchange between the atmosphere and the Earth’s oceans and terrestrial ecosystems remains a primary uncertainty in climate model projections (IPCC, 2007). Predicting the response of global carbon fluxes to expected changes in atmospheric CO2, temperature, precipitation, and surface winds and ocean currents requires a better understanding of how and why these fluxes vary on synoptic to decadal timescales.

In September 1996, a sampling program to measure temperature in the upper 800 m of ocean across Drake Passage in the Southern Ocean was initiated on the U.S. Antarctic Program (USAP) vessel, the ARSV Laurence M. Gould (LMG) to study the upper ocean temperature variability (Figure 1). Additional programs designed to sample the upper ocean were subsequently added to the LMG: near-surface currents and acoustic backscatter, near surface partial pressure of carbon dioxide, together with discrete sea surface samples for total carbon, nutrients, and oxygen. The combined time series of physical and biogeochemical measurements represents one of the most complete, longest running and densely sampled time series in the Southern Ocean with a combination of measurements taken from the atmosphere, the air-sea interface and the upper 1000 m of the ocean.

A major achievement of the Drake Passage time series is to better understand interactions between physical mechanisms and biogeochemical cycling over a range of temporal and spatial scales that will improve predictions of how this critical region will respond to future climate change. Collectively the measurements in Drake Passage have provided much insight as to the characteristics, mechanisms and impacts of the processes and changes that are occurring within the Southern Ocean. The observations provide much needed validation and constraints on remotely sensed measurements and numerical models in the sparsely sampled Southern Ocean. The project has also promoted training and learning through the involvement of graduate students and a postdoctoral fellow.
